Posts.Content: Jan 7, 2010 12:58PM Luah wrote: I too worry about this, being on dose dense AC with the A pushed (I am going to ask about IV), yet I feel being triple negative, I have to be as aggressive as possible. I did read up on some of the studies on the long-term effects on A, and as I recall once you are over 400 mg (? not sure of measure, I'll be up to 416 by last treatment), the risk of LVF was about 5%, so not trivial but certainly less than my odds of cancer recurrence.   I had an EKO and muga prior to treatment, but wouldn't it make sense to do that again midway to see how your heart is holding up?   Are any of you getting that? I wonder what good a baseline is if they don't use that to make treatment decisions, only to blame the chemo for later damage.  I know for 2-3 days following treatment, I get a pounding heartbeat sometimes, even a fluttery feeling with irregular pulse, that just passes in a few moments. I thought this might be the steroid, but the sheet I have doesn't list that as a SE. So I've reported it to my onc's nurse today... haven't heard back yet.
Posts.Title: Dangers of AC chemo long after treatment ends navygirl Luah

Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2010 02:31PM Luah wrote: My second treatment of AC was done by a new nurse at the cancer center (although she said she'd be in oncology for 30 years) and I was horrifed to see the A pushed in something under 5 minutes (which I now understand is the minimum).  I had no reaction at the time, but who knows later... Otter, congrats to you for being so well-informed and advocating on your behalf. I wish I had spoken up at the time - I had reservations about the nurse, but didn't make a fuss, and should have. I also like to do a lot of research and the first time I met with my onco she seemed a bit irritated with me, but she has since improved and is now receptive to my questions and challenges, and listens!  Sometimes I think it takes them a while to figure out what kind of patient they have in front of them - some pts like to turn their care over to a trusted expert - and some like to take a  more active role. On the other hand, some docs will never get it!
Posts.Title: Dangers of AC chemo long after treatment ends navygirl Luah

Posts.Content: Nov 2, 2009 02:15AM Luah wrote: Thanks for following up 2Hands4me.  The pinkness seemed to settle down after last weekend - only a bit in the crease of my armpit now. Icy feeling is gone too.  But my skin is still supersensitive, inside arm elbow to armpit and across my lumpectomied (is that a word?) breast. Axillary incision is sore too. I'm seeing my surgeon for follow-up (and path report - yikes!) tomorrow, so will see what she says. In the meantime, I searched and found lots on these boards (thank you ladies!) about the sensitive sandpapery feeling.  Today, I've been trying to massage a bit to see if that helps settle down the brain-nerve mess-up.
Posts.Title: Oh the joys of SNB recovery - let me count the ways Luah 2z54

Posts.Content: Luah wrote: Hi ladies: Happy to say my lump incision is all good, but SNB - ugh! Had 3 nodes removed a week ago.  During the last 48 hours I think I have felt any and all of the following at various times: - sore, sandpaper feeling - periods of stinging - knifelike stabs - tightness - like a rubber band being stretched - icy-water flowing through my arm, shoulder to finger-tips This morning I noticed my skin was "pinkened" and warm in the area next to and in front of the incision, kinda spreading from the armpit area over the top of my breast. Doc's office said to watch til tomorrow and call back if not better - she'd try to squeeze me in for a look-see. I don't want to over-react, but if it's possibly the start of an infection(?), I really don't want to be waiting it out over the weekend.  Anyone else experience this? How did it resolve, and how long did it take? We've been through some things together/With trunks of memories still to come/Long may you run (Neil Young). Posts.Content: Sep 25, 2009 10:47AM Luah wrote: There are lots of stats, generally, on the effectiveness of lumpectomy & rads vs. mastectomy (I am not sure about repeat procedures to get clear margins)... (from Dr. Susan Love) "Large randomized studies with as much as 20 years of follow-up have shown that both approaches-mastectomy and lumpectomy followed by radiation-result in the same survival rates." (from the National Cancer Institute): Early-stage breast cancer patients who choose lumpectomy and radiation will live as long as women who opt for a mastectomy -- whether or not they also choose to have reconstruction. Your odds for recurrence of early-stage breast cancer are around 10% (1 in 10) within 12 years of lumpectomy and radiation. If you have a mastectomy, your risk of recurrence is about 5% (1 in 20) on the same side within 12 years of surgery; that risk is the same regardless of reconstruction surgery. ... and there are cosmetic reasons which are individual, and only your own BS can advise you on... ... and then there is your own psychology, biases, values etc..... Ultimately you will decide what feels right for you.

You need to do what feels right for you... and your family will need to support that decision. I wish you well.

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2010 01:50PM Luah wrote: I agree with Beesie and others above re lumpectomy.  It's what I chose too.  The fear of local recurrence is not really the issue.  And yet.... After surgery, my pathology came back triple negative, which puts me at a higher risk of recurrence (at least in the early years) compared with hormone+ cancers.  So what I now worry about is if this aggressive cancer comes back, will screening find it before it has another chance to spread beyond the breast? (mammos didn't work the first time).  And now that I have had levels 1 and 2 lymph nodes removed, is there not more risk of a locally recurring cancer hopping on the freeway to distant parts of my body if it does recur?  That's where a local recurrence suddenly doesn't seem so benign... I want to discuss this with my docs, but any thoughts?

I actually don't mind it - and went topless on the weekend for a trip to Stratford, where I knew I wouldn't run into anybody I knew. It felt so liberating -- and to feel the sun and wind in your hair - fantastic!!  But I am a little reluctant to give up my hats and scarves closer to home, because people (who "don't know") are used to seeing me in my brown-blonde wig or fall - and I don't feel like explaining the drastic change.   How do you ladies deal with this?   Somehow I feel if I could throw some ash-blonde on my hair, I'd look a bit like Annie Lennox - which wouldn't be so bad.  At least it might look like a deliberate style change.

Posts.Content: Jul 10, 2011 06:30PM - edited Jul 10, 2011 06:32PM by Luah I am not sure standard of care has changed yet, but the research cited above showed how radiation can be an appropriate treatment for women with 1-3 involved nodes instead of ALND. Micromets is a different story, and as different studies show different things about their significance in terms of treatment/prognosis, doctors may take different approaches, depending on your pathology and planned treatment. They may suggest leaving it, leaving it to chemo, radiating, or doing surgery. The important thing is to ask lots of questions, challenge them even, and have them defend their recommendation. As this is a murky area, you may not get clearcut direction... do what feels right, ultimately it's up to you....as agonizing as that is... and don't look back.  Fwiw, I had 4 senitnels drawn, 1 with isolated cells, another with so many isolated cells the pathologist said it should be considered micromets, even though the cells weren't clumped. Being triple negative with a sizable tumour (actually 2), I knew I was doing chemo anyway... the question was, ALND or extra rads to the nodes? Research was just beginning to appear about radiation in place of ALND, but in the end I chose ALND because I wanted evidence if any additional nodes were affected (they weren't) - rather than trusting chemo and rads to do it. I've had no LE but I'm not sure I would make that same choice today - hard to say.

Posts.Content: Nov 30, 2011 02:31PM - edited Nov 30, 2011 02:34PM by Luah (edited to add) AnneNYC, my message crossed with yours... we had the same idea!) There has been research on metronomic chemotherapy. This, from 2006: http://www.cancer.gov/aboutnci/ncicancerbulletin/archive/2006/062706/page4 These trials are just a few of the ongoing trials for BC metronomic chemotherapy: http://www.clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT00496665?term=metronomic+chemotherapy&rank=1 http://www.clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT00925652?term=metronomic+chemotherapy&rank=3 http://www.clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT01329627?term=metronomic+chemotherapy&rank=6 The great thing about that nasty medical/industrial complex  is they are actually required by law to register their clinical trials, so results can be tracked through a publicly available, easily searchable online data bank.  To Patmom and others: If you respect the time and trust of users of this site, please cite credible sources for your posted data.
Posts.Title: Chemo and Breast Cancer - Another Perspective PlantLover LtotheK

Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2012 04:31PM Luah wrote: I agree with Deanna -- you need to get input/information from a medical oncologist before deciding whether or not to do chemo first. Nothing wrong with keeping the BS appointment and asking more questions about surgery... and taking a few more days to do the onco research. Do you know the hormone status of your mother's tumour from the biopsy? That may affect her decision on which to do first. She should also expect to be referred for several tests: breast MRI, abdominal ultrasound, chest Xray, bone scan and/ or PET. This helps them detect any other signs of cancer and properly stage her cancer... and may also affect next treatment step. It is a lot ot take in. Take baby steps, research reputable sources of information, and don't hesitate to ask lots of questions with her docs and here.

Posts.Content: Dec 1, 2011 11:47AM Luah wrote: Alaska: I doubt there is a single patient, doctor or researcher that is content with the status quo when it comes to cancer. That is why research is going on ALL THE TIME. There has been significant advances in chemotherapy options over the past 20 years. For others with a pathology like mine, yes, I would certainly encourage them to do the latest generation chemotherapy. Are you suggesting it be boycotted to register dissatisfaction with the rate of progress? That would be reckless and ridiculous. I don't see how taking advantage of the latest therapies is mutually exclusive to advocacy for additional research and improvement.
Posts.Title: Chemo and Breast Cancer - Another Perspective PlantLover LtotheK

Posts.Content: Dec 1, 2011 06:27PM Luah wrote: AA: cancermath.net provides an excellent predictive tool on the net benefit of various chemo regimens, depending on your tumour size, receptor status, grade, type and node status. My own calculation (and I am triple negative so I don't have the luxury of choosing other medical treatments) goes from 66% to 82% survival 10 years out - that's a net improvement of about 25%, I'll take it. Obviously this tool isn't perfect, but it's something to consider. I don't agree with your perception that chemo is recommended to the exclusion of other therapies, such as hormonal. In recent years, for example, the oncotype test has been enormously helpful in trying to predict who might benefit most (and least) from chemo. Many many ER+ women with low scores forfeit chemo as a result - and this would not have been the case 10 years ago. There have indeed been many medical treatment advances too - Herceptin has been huge for Her2+.  I understand your impatience - there is not yet a proven biologic therapy that can be put to wide use for TN treatment, for example - but at the same time I value, respect, support and advocate for the scientific process.
Posts.Title: Chemo and Breast Cancer - Another Perspective PlantLover LtotheK

Posts.Content: Dec 1, 2011 03:33PM Luah wrote: AA: Unfortunately well-designed clinical trials with good sampling take time to execute and report. The fact that they are so rigorous should give us all comfort not distress, even as we wish things would move faster. And yes of course they would design initial trials as trastuzumab alongside chemo, as chemo is standard of care (and I doubt too many peope would want to be recruited into a trial where they could get randomized to a totally unproven drug - I know I wouldn't!) If trastusumab proves highly effective alongside chemo, I would bet you will see some clinical trials testing it as a single agent -- and yes, probably with metastatic patients to start or those who can't tolerate chemo. It's a matter of building knowledge one step at a time, isolating one factor at a time, with minimal risk to the patient. That's how medical science works. It doesn't mean it's a conspiracy for profit.
Posts.Title: Chemo and Breast Cancer - Another Perspective PlantLover LtotheK

Posts.Content: Nov 30, 2011 11:11AM Luah wrote: Interesting discussion, I'm just peeved as hell that I sat through (wasted) 10 minutes with that Goldberg guy and didn't get the answer Princess promised: what causes cancer? (Please don't over-promise when posting links.) He talked a lot about pesticides which are known carcinogens - how is that new? And I agree with lassie: If it's all a medical/pharma/industrial conspiracy to make money, why do publicly funded systems like Canada's also rely on surgery, chemo and radiation to treat cancer?   For me, the issue is that the alternative route discounts the traditional medical interventions and risks lives (I watched a friend die while pursuing alternative therapies over chemo)... whereas having given myself the best evidence-based shot for my cancer survival with surgery, chemo and radiation, I can now integrate some alternative options into my lifestyle: exercise, vit D3, green tea, crustaceous veggies, turmeric and perhaps (no evidence and no guarantees) prolong my survival. By the way, isn't anyone else concerned about the fact that supplements aren't regulated the way drugs are? Who knows what you're getting....
